stimulusHtml: After a long time, as the rocket moves farther away from the planet, what happens to the rocket’s speed, and what reasoning supports the claim?

features.html: A rocket is launched straight upward from the surface of a planet that has no atmosphere. The rocket very quickly reaches escape velocity. At that instant, the rocket’s engine turns off.

choicesHtml: The speed approaches zero. As the rocket moves farther away from the planet, both the potential energy of the rocket-planet system and kinetic energy of the rocket approach zero.
The speed approaches zero. Even if the rocket moves beyond the planet’s gravity there must always be a force from the engine to keep it moving.
The speed approaches a positive value. Once the rocket is beyond the planet’s gravity its speed remains constant because the net force on it is zero.
The speed approaches a positive value. The potential energy of the rocket-planet system is increasing, and the rocket’s kinetic energy is already a positive value.
